quote: We are approaching Starbase   one-seven-nine.
Half impulse, Mister Crusher.
Going to half impulse.
Captain, this is the bridge. We   have arrived at Starbase   one-seven-nine.
Acknowledged, Number One.
Establish position -- zero-nine-zero mark   three-seven-five -- at   twenty-seven thousand   kilometers.
Aye, sir.
Open hailing frequencies,   Lieutenant.
Hailing frequencies open.
Starbase one-seven-nine, this is   the USS Enterprise.
Enterprise, this is Starbase   one-seven-nine. We are ready for   transfer on your mark.
Thank you.
Commander Data, you have the   bridge. Ensign Crusher, you will   accompany me.
Starbase one-seven-nine. We are   ready to commence transfer.
Acknowledge Enterprise. Begin   transfer.
This is my last chance to say that   it has been a pleasure to serve   with you and to wish you luck on   your new assignment. You have   served the Enterprise well.       No tears, please.
Energize.
Enterprise ready. Beam aboard.

Welcome aboard the Enterprise.   I'm Commander William Riker, your   first officer. Those of you who   are here as replacements will step   outside and Lieutenant Lewis will   assign you to crew quarters.       Ensign, you are here on the   exchange program, you'll follow   Mister Crusher.
Mordoc, what are you doing here?   You couldn't have graduated from   the Academy already.
I am not Mordoc. I am Mendon.   Ensign Mendon of the planet   Benzar.
I'm sorry sir. I thought you were   a friend... Mordoc...       ... You look just like him.
We are from the same   geostructure. Naturally we look   alike.
How do you tell each other apart?
We just do.
Well, nice to have you here   Ensign. There will be a   briefing and indoctrination   session as soon as you settle in.
I want to tell you how happy I   am to be assigned to the   Enterprise. It wasn't just luck.   I requested it. I know I can   be of great help to the ship.
Yes, of course. Now if you'll   just follow Ensign Crusher.
Yes sir.
Commander Riker, report to the   Phaser Range, please...
On the way.
I was wondering if you had any   feelings about the Officer   Exchange Program that has been   initiated by Starfleet Command.
scene: 13   INT. PHASER RANGE - CLOSE ON TARGET (OPTICAL)

quote: Just positive ones sir. I've   already welcomed Ensign Mendon   on board and he certainly seems   eager to please.
scene: 13   INT. PHASER RANGE - CLOSE ON TARGET (OPTICAL)

quote: That's a Benzite trait.       It's been suggested that one of   the officers on the Enterprise   might like to participate in this   exchange program.
scene: 13   INT. PHASER RANGE - CLOSE ON TARGET (OPTICAL)

quote: Probably a good idea.
scene: 13   INT. PHASER RANGE - CLOSE ON TARGET (OPTICAL)

quote: There's a Klingon vessel in the   vicinity.
scene: 13   INT. PHASER RANGE - CLOSE ON TARGET (OPTICAL)

quote: I don't recall ever hearing of   a Federation officer serving on   a Klingon vessel.
scene: 13   INT. PHASER RANGE - CLOSE ON TARGET (OPTICAL)

quote: Neither have I.
scene: 13   INT. PHASER RANGE - CLOSE ON TARGET (OPTICAL)

quote: It could be beneficial.
scene: 13   INT. PHASER RANGE - CLOSE ON TARGET (OPTICAL)

quote: Having Worf on board certainly   has been.
scene: 13   INT. PHASER RANGE - CLOSE ON TARGET (OPTICAL)

quote: Yes sir, that's true.       Who did you intend to send?
scene: 13   INT. PHASER RANGE - CLOSE ON TARGET (OPTICAL)

quote: I was going to ask for a   volunteer.
scene: 13   INT. PHASER RANGE - CLOSE ON TARGET (OPTICAL)

quote: I wouldn't mind, sir.
scene: 13   INT. PHASER RANGE - CLOSE ON TARGET (OPTICAL)

quote: What was that, Number One?
scene: 13   INT. PHASER RANGE - CLOSE ON TARGET (OPTICAL)

quote: I said I wouldn't mind the   assignment.
scene: 13   INT. PHASER RANGE - CLOSE ON TARGET (OPTICAL)

quote: Any particular reason?
scene: 13   INT. PHASER RANGE - CLOSE ON TARGET (OPTICAL)

quote: Because nobody has ever done it   before.
scene: 13   INT. PHASER RANGE - CLOSE ON TARGET (OPTICAL)

quote: I'll notify starbase of your   acceptance... They'll contact the   Klingon vessel and make the   arrangements.
scene: 13   INT. PHASER RANGE - CLOSE ON TARGET (OPTICAL)

quote: Captain's log, stardate 42606.5.   I have informed the staff of   Commander Riker's temporary duty   assignment and we have departed   from Starbase one-seven-nine and   are headed for a rendezvous with   the Klingon vessel, the Pagh.
I have studied and know everything   about my heritage.

Then you are the one to fill me   in on something that I'm not   clear about.       It's my understanding that one   of the duties of the first officer   on a Klingon ship is to   assassinate the captain.
Yes sir.
Wouldn't that bring about chaos?

Of course not. When and if the   captain becomes weak and unable   to perform, it is expected that   his honorable retirement should   be assisted by his "first."       The second officer would   assassinate you for the same   reasons.
This method of attrition could   take a little getting used to.
The Klingon system has operated   successfully for centuries.
It is different.
Many things will be different.
That's a wonderful method of   maintaining a constant control   factor over defensive shields,   but I'm sure there's a way to   improve response time.
Oh, sorry, didn't mean to   interrupt you... Just thought I   could be of some help, however   I am correct in what I said.
That is superb designing,   absolutely first rate.
Yes it is. Would you care to   be more specific?
The input sampling. It's simple   yet efficient enough. Of course   a minor change of the helm   readout would be much more   helpful in emergency situations.
We've never had any trouble with   it. Have you seen it work?
Not in a practical exercise, but   in theory... my theory... it would   be more than a marginal   improvement. I'll have to mention   this to the captain.
You're going to advise Captain   Picard?
Captain Picard... I'll have to   discuss these improvements with   him.       He is open to some astute   observations, isn't he?
Well, I've never heard Captain   Picard refuse to listen to his   officers.
Outstanding! Pretty soon we'll   get things running perfectly.
What is this?
A Klingon delicacy. That's heart   of targ -- this is pipius claw.   And this is stewed "gagh."
"Gagh"?
Serpent worms... would you like   to know how they're prepared?
No thanks. I've never heard of   a Klingon starving to death on   one of their own vessels, but you   might.
Not if I weaken first.
I know all about that. Their   beliefs may be somewhat brutal   but usually what kills us, kills   them.
(sniffing an awful     drink)   That's something to look forward   to. Would you like a drink,   Doctor?
I'm abstaining in honor of your   last hour on board.
Your sacrifice will not go   unnoticed.
I understand the theory of the   feast before the transfer. I've   done the same thing dozens of   times. However, I usually made   more civil choices.
These are the most civil choices.
I see... Well, their food may be   somewhat backward but the Klingons   are efficient, loyal to their   beliefs, and are regulated by a   strict code of ethics.
True enough. They tend to lean   towards a Samurai civilization   that is thousands of years old.
But they are pure in that   tradition.
This is a great opportunity,   Number One. We really know so   little about them. We have so   much to learn.       I think I envy you, Will Riker.
An emergency transponder?
Slightly altered to transmit an   omnidirectional signal and an   emergency call.
Are you sensing some trouble   that I don't?
Simply a security precaution.   I want to insure your return to   this ship.
Sentiment, Lieutenant Worf?
Efficiency, Commander.
I understand. Thank you,   Lieutenant.
We have a Klingon vessel   approaching.
Hailing frequencies open.
They are returning our hail in   proper language. It is the Pagh.
On viewscreen.
I am Jean-Luc Picard, captain of   the Enterprise.
And I am Captain Kargan of the   Pagh. Beam your first officer   on board immediately.
We are preparing to do so.   You're getting a good man,   Captain Kargan.
Thank you for your opinion but   I will judge that for myself.   Screen off.
Not very hospitable are they?
That is not your concern. Observe   your station, Ensign Mendon.
Didn't mean to offend you.
You didn't...       ... Yet.
Transporter Room, prepare to beam   Commander Riker aboard the Pagh.
Ready, Captain.
Good Luck, Commander.
Thank you sir.
On your command, Will.
Energize.
Viewscreen off. Resume course.
Aye sir.
Take over Commander Data, I'll   be in my quarters.
Yes sir.
Sir, I'm Ensign Mendon. I just   wanted to tell you how pleased   I am to be aboard the Enterprise.
Yes, of course. Nice to have you   on board.
If you have a few minutes I've   noted a few procedural items that   could speed up operations on the   bridge.
I pick things up very quickly.
I'm sure you do Ensign, you   have an excellent record.   However, on the Enterprise we use   the chain of command. You may   report your observations to   Lieutenant Worf.
I didn't mean to challenge your   authority...       ... I just wanted to impress upon   you...
No need to apologize Ensign...   we should have explained it better   during indoctrination.
Ensign Mendon... You may impress   me.
Something wrong?
No, Commander.       It's just I have never seen anyone   of your species before...
I'm just your average everyday   human who happens to be a   commander. Now what are your   orders?
I am to escort you to the captain.
Proceed.
I am Commander William Riker of   the Starship Enterprise.
That is incorrect.
I don't understand.
You are Commander Riker, first   officer of the Klingon Cruiser   Pagh, or do you intend to   disobey Federation orders?
I have no such intentions,   Captain.
Exactly where are your loyalties,   Commander?
I'm afraid I still don't   understand.

This ship is equipped with our   best weapons and our finest   warriors. Although we are on a   peaceful mission we are prepared   to go into battle instantly. I   know I can count on every Klingon   warrior in this crew to serve and   die in that battle. So I ask   again Commander Riker,       where are your loyalties?
I have been assigned here to serve   this ship and to obey your orders.   I will do exactly that.
Will you take an oath to that   effect?
I just did.
yI-Har-Qo! nep-we' ghaH! (Do   not believe him! He lies!)
Hol-chaj yI-jatlh. (Speak in   their language.)       This is your second officer,   Lieutenant Klag.
Was there something you wanted   to say to me, Lieutenant?
Yes sir.       I don't believe you.
Then I take it you challenge my   authority over you.
Correct.
And your position in this,   Captain?
I would call it your first command   decision.
My oath is between Captain Kargan   and myself. Your only concern   is how to obey my orders.       Or do you prefer the rank of   prisoner over that of lieutenant?
I will take your orders.
And you, Commander Riker, will   obey my orders.
Agreed, Captain Kargan.
Sir, the automatic scan has   registered some unknown substance   on the aft quarter of the exterior   skin of the dorsal fin.
Zero in on that location and   define.
I've located it sir. The dorsal   of the Engineering Section.
On viewscreen. Focus on area.   Magnification factor ten.
Increase magnification to   twenty.
Analyze.

The substance appears to be a rare   form of subatomic "bacteria,"   capable of doubling every fifteen   minutes. It seems to be reacting   with two of the compounds present   in the Enterprise structure.
Determine origin.
I noticed it when I did an   intensive scan of the Pagh,   the Klingon ship.
And you informed no one?
I have not yet completed my full   analysis.
You are supposed to report   whatever is out of the ordinary.   This falls into that category.
But sir, as I said I have not yet   completed my analysis. It would   be improper to report it until   then.
How did you come by that   decision?

It is a Benzite regulation. No   officer on the deck of one of our   ships would report an occurrence   like this until he had a full   analysis and a resolution.       I have simply followed proper   procedures.
It is our procedure for you to   bring to the attention of command   any possibility of danger. You   will not make those decisions.       Is that clear, Ensign Mendon?
Yes sir.
Fine. Now I want you to complete   the analysis and determine the   danger not only to this ship but   the Klingon vessel as well.
Yes Captain... That will take a   couple of hours.
You'll remain at your station   until it is complete, then report   to me. Lieutenant Worf will   supervise you.
Yes sir.
... and then I will instruct you   in Enterprise etiquette.

Commander's log, supplemental,   Stardate 42607.8. I have been   on the Pagh a short time but long   enough to be impressed with the   abilities and singlemindedness   of the Klingons. I can now see   why they have gained the respect   of Captain Picard.
You're not eating very much.
Well, I'm not that hungry.
Is the food all right, Commander?
Fine. The "pipius" was excellent,   and I also liked the "Bregit   lungs."
And the Rokeg blood pie?
Excellent.
Then you'll also like this.
This is "gagh," isn't it?
Very good. You did some research   on our nutritional choices.
Yes... but this is still moving.
"Gagh" is always best when served   live.       Would you like something "easier"?
Easier?
If Klingon food is too strong for   you, perhaps I could get one of   the females to breast feed you.
Don't tell me you're still   concerned about my not   weakening?
Look around. You'll see that   there are no old warriors.
Of course, I'm sure they all died   with honor.
Exactly. You may live long enough   to learn about us.
He's not very attractive, but   I will have him.
They are inquisitive. They would   like to know how you would endure.
Endure what?
Them.
One or both?
It is confirmed that the organisms   feed on some of the compounds that   make up the Enterprise hull.
And the Klingon ship, the Pagh?
They are much more susceptible.   Their hull contains all of the   compounds.
Project your calculations.
According to the rate of   reproduction there should be a   twelve centimeter hole in the   Klingon hull at this time.
Signal them at once and advise   them. Change our course to   attempt an intercept. We will   make every attempt to cleanse the   vessel and assist with repairs.
It will take some time to locate   them. They are on undesignated   maneuvers in the Pheben solar   system.
Then start immediately. Alert   Engineering of this situation.   Ensign Crusher, adjust course   toward the proper sector.
Aye sir. Shall we prepare for   warp speed?
Yes...       ... and hope that we get there   in time.
Commander Riker to the bridge.
On monitor. Tell me Commander   Riker, what do you make of this?
I felt no collision. Were we hit   by a small meteor?
There was no collision.
Corrosion then.
No, not corrosion.
Science Station, analyze.
We already have and fortunately   the cavity opened into a section   that could withstand the change   in pressure.
Then what is it?
A space organism eating away at   our hull. Our estimate is that   in less than eight hours we will   have lost too much of our shell   to remain intact.
You must have a way to repair   it.
I'm afraid not.
There has to be. Where did this   come from?
"Where" might be the answer.       The only contact we had was with   the Enterprise.
There was no direct contact with   the Enterprise.
Tactics Officer, report to   Commander Riker.
The Enterprise did conduct an   intensive scan of this vessel.
It's normal procedure.
What type of beam did the   Enterprise use to create this   damage in our hull?
None! Why would they do that?   We are allies.
My logs indicate that the   Enterprise directed an intense   scanning beam at this specific   area for a duration of two   minutes.
Explain that.
I can't.
It could be a weapon.
Wait a minute. Why? There's   no new weapon. The Enterprise   has no reason to do this,   especially not with me on board.   It makes no sense.
"Why" is no longer important.   What is important is our response   to this attack.       Engage cloaking device. Change   course to intercept the   Enterprise.
Captain, what do you intend to   do?
Intend? There is only one   response. We intend to attack   the Enterprise and destroy it!!
You seem to be making progress.   You've already eliminated half   the possibilities.
Thank you, but I seem to have   become efficient a little later   than was needed. It was my   responsibility to learn and adapt   to the Enterprise's regulations.   I didn't do that.
Not really, it was an error.   Captain Picard may not like them,   but he does know they can happen   from time to time.
I failed, I had an opportunity   to show the captain my superior   abilities and I failed. I can   never recover from that.
It was a mistake... That's all.   You didn't put the organism on   the hull. You discovered it and   you were attempting to analyze   it. All you did was mess up a   little on the ship's protocol.
I know you're trying to be nice   to me and I appreciate it. What   I don't understand is why?
Why not? I thought you could use   a friend.
Thank you. I only hope I can   learn your ways before I "mess" up   again. I imagine my methods seem   foolish to you.

They are different. But that's   what this exchange program is all   about... You learn the way we   do things and bring that   information back to your command.   It's up to you to decide which   way is better for you.       It's easy. All you have to do   is learn.
You're right. I'll try your   way...    (turns back to Science     Station)   I'll work even harder than before.   I'll succeed brilliantly.
What is the status?
Unchanged. The rate of increase   continues.
Commander Riker, check the   organism growth with Engineering.
Keep him under scrutiny. I'm   not sure I trust him.
I'm not totally convinced that   Riker knew of any plot against   us. If he did then why would he   have come on board?
Because he was ordered to.
To die?
To be ordered to die is an   expectation for any officer at   any time.
For a Klingon perhaps, but Riker's   people do not volunteer for death   so easily. Even so, Riker may   be a spy, but he's no coward.
That only proves that he is   intelligent and that you may not   be as strong as you used to be.
Captain, we have picked up the   Enterprise.
So soon?
The Enterprise is on an intercept   course with us.
You almost had me believing that   perhaps this was a   misunderstanding.
Yes... So?
The Enterprise has changed course   and is following us. Why?
I don't know. Let's ask them.
The reason is obvious. Their   intent is clear. How long before   we have contact?
Less than fifteen minutes, sir.
Put the ship on battle alert.   Arm all photon torpedoes and put   phasers on full power. Let them   charge into their destruction.
Sir, bearings show that we should   be in contact with the Klingon   ship.
Slow to impulse speed. Continue   on course.
Aye sir, impulse speed.
Hailing frequencies open. There   is no response.
Continue to transmit.
The Pagh is either destroyed or   cloaked.
Begin intensive scan for debris.   Conduct a thorough search of the   area.
The Enterprise has slowed to   impulse speed and is making an   intensive sweep.
Hold your position. Let them come   to us.
They may be here to help you...   Don't be a fool!
Do not forget my rank.
I haven't. I am simply trying   to get you to understand.
I fully understand... Now you   understand.       I am still the captain of this   vessel and you are still crew and   sworn to obey me. You gave me   your oath.
Yes sir, I did.
Then fulfill that oath and serve   this ship as you swore to.       Tell me of the surest method of   attack against the Enterprise.
I can't.
You must tell me. It is a matter   of honor and loyalty.
I cannot surrender the secrets   of Starfleet and the Enterprise   to you.
Then if your word is no good, how   can we trust any of your people?
I won't break any vow I took in   the past. I also swore a loyalty   to your ship and I will keep that.
They are in conflict!

No sir, they are not! I will obey   your orders. I will serve this   ship as first officer, and in an   attack against the Enterprise I   will die along with this crew...   but I will not dishonor my oath   to the Enterprise.

If you had agreed to disclose   those facts about the Enterprise   I would have labelled you a   traitor and killed you on the   spot...       Instead you will die with us.   You will die like a Klingon.
So be it.
Sir, I have something to report   to you immediately.
scene: 73   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - SCIENCE ONE STATION

quote: Go ahead, Ensign.
scene: 73   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - SCIENCE ONE STATION

quote: I have managed to isolate the   organism on our hull.
scene: 73   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - SCIENCE ONE STATION

quote: Spare me the technical details...   just the results.
scene: 73   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - SCIENCE ONE STATION

quote: They are of a sub-micron form.   They are controllable and can   be removed from the hulls of both   ships.
scene: 73   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - SCIENCE ONE STATION

quote: Thank you Ensign, well done.   Prepare whatever procedures are   necessary.       Lieutenant Worf, add this   information to hailing messages.
scene: 73   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - SCIENCE ONE STATION

quote: Aye sir. Still no response.
scene: 73   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - SCIENCE ONE STATION

quote: The Enterprise has changed hailing   messages. They now include a   promise of cleaning the organisms   and assisting in repairs.
They mean it... They will help.
And I mean what I say.       Arm all weapons... Prepare for   attack...

Captain's log, supplemental,   Stardate 42608.2. Although our   search has been extensive, we are   still unable to locate the   Klingon ship or any debris. The   absence of both leaves us puzzled   and somewhat tentative.
Considering the absence of debris,   it is reasonable to assume the   Klingon vessel is in the vicinity   and cloaked.
Agreed.
Since we do not know their intent   I recommend we go to Red Alert.
Make it so.
The Enterprise has raised its   shields.
It is normal procedure when   entering into a suspicious   situation. The act is not   aggressive. The Enterprise will   not fire first.
Then they are fools, for we will.
You'll get only one shot.
We will only need one. Arm all   phasers and torpedoes. Prepare   to fire them simultaneously.
Then I recommend you do not fire   until you are within forty   thousand kilometers.
Why?
It will reduce their response   time.
You are honoring your promise to   serve us.
Would you do less?
No.       You will give the order to fire,   Commander Riker.       Call out distances.       Any questions, Mister Riker?
Just something I have to say...       ... I dispute your judgment. Your   reasons for forcing this   confrontation are not valid.
Are you finished?
Yes sir.
Then commence with attack as   ordered.
Fifty-five thousand kilometers   and closing.
Is that a weapon?
No sir, it is a signaling device.
Hand it to me, Commander.
We are getting an emergency signal   from a command transponder.   Location nine-three-five mark   six-one-three... Frequency   and code designate it as Commander   Riker.
Chief O'Brien, align with   emergency transponder signal.
Yes Captain. We are not yet in   safe range for a transfer and   defensive shields are still in   place.
scene: 83   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - INTERCUT AS NEEDED

quote: We may have to stretch it a   little. On my command.
scene: 83   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - INTERCUT AS NEEDED

quote: Forty-eight thousand.
scene: 83   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - INTERCUT AS NEEDED

quote: Lieutenant Worf to the Transporter   Room. Doctor Pulaski will   accompany you. Mendon take over   the count.
scene: 83   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - INTERCUT AS NEEDED

quote: Yes sir. Forty-five thousand and   still closing.
scene: 83   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - INTERCUT AS NEEDED

quote: Forty-four thousand.
scene: 83   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - INTERCUT AS NEEDED

quote: Transporter Room, ready. You will   control defensive shields...
scene: 83   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - INTERCUT AS NEEDED

quote: Ready sir.
Forty thousand...
Forty thousand.
Prepare to drop cloaking shields   and fire. Steady...
Transporter Room, energize.
Hold where you are Klag. I have   relieved Captain Kargan. He was   acting in an irrational manner.   I am now your captain!!       Serve this ship as I have!
Defensive shields back in place.
Who are you?
I am Lieutenant Worf of the   Starship Enterprise.
Riker has no honor... He tricked   me!!
He's barely stunned.
Of course, he is a Klingon   captain.
That's great, but where's Will   Riker?
Cloaking shields off.
Obey my orders.
We will be destroyed.
If we are, it will be in battle   and I will die with you.       Now, cloaking shields off!
It is the Pagh sir. It has all   armament locked on us and ready   to fire.
Hold position. Hailing   frequencies open.       Calling the Pagh. This is the   Enterprise. We are here to assist   you. Do not fire.
They will not believe you.
Pagh... Do you read me??
Enterprise, this is Captain   William Riker of the Klingon   vessel, the Pagh.       I order you to lower your shields   and surrender.
Lower shields.       Surrender as ordered.
I demand to be beamed back aboard   my vessel.
Transporter Chief, prepare to beam   Captain Kargan aboard the Pagh.    (to Riker, who has     heard)   Captain Riker, preparations are   ready for immediate repairs to   your ship.
Thank you, Captain Picard.
You should have killed me.
I don't want your command.
You tricked me so you could have   it.
And I give it back to you now.
Then return to your position.
No more, Captain Kargan...
Get him off my ship!
Yes, Captain.
You understand the Klingons better   than I thought.
Thank you, my friend.
That might be one of the shortest   assignments in the history of   Starfleet.
You're wrong, Number One... it   was almost the longest.       You did well.
Thank you. I learned quite a bit.
Apparently not how to duck.
When not to duck would be more   accurate.
If that was the intention...   Welcome aboard.
Thank you. Your little toy   worked.
I'm glad it did, sir.
You come from a very brave and   unique race. I'm glad you're here   on the Enterprise.
Thank you, Commander...       ... and welcome home.
